awd_titl_txt: ISBA 2020: 15th World Meeting of the International Society for Bayesian Analysis -- June 29-July 3, 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports travel for participants in the 2020 World Meeting of the International Society for Bayesian Analysis (ISBA) held in Kunming, China, June 29 - July 3, 2020. The conference themes include theory, modeling, and applications in Bayesian statistics. The grant provides support for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers from U.S.-based institutions to travel to the conference. Particular emphasis is given to supporting women and members of underrepresented groups.

Statisticians play a critical role in the analysis of noisy, complex data that are used to make scientific discoveries as well as practical decisions under uncertainty. Bayesian statistics provides a coherent framework that facilitates integrating information from different sources and communicates findings and conclusions using probabilities. As a result, Bayesian approaches have been widely adopted in a variety of modern applications in areas such as biology, physics, psychology, economics, finance, environmental science, and engineering, along with many others. Bayesian models and methods are also the foundation for many recent developments in machine learning and artificial intelligence. The 2020 ISBA World Meeting brings together the diverse international community of researchers and practitioners who develop and use Bayesian statistical methods for sharing recent findings, exchanging ideas, and discussing new, challenging problems. The international meeting exposes participants to ideas and colleagues from other countries, with whom they may not ordinarily interact. Participation in the conference will help inform junior statisticians about the key problems and methods that shape research in modern Bayesian statistics and provide them with opportunities to learn from more established researchers and to build collaborative relationships.

Additional information is available on the meeting web page https://bayesian.org/isba2020-home/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project originally involved a request for junior travel support for the 2020 World Meeting of the International Society for Bayesian Analysis (ISBA), which was planned to be held in Kunming, China, June 28---July 3, 2020. Due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, the conference was converted to an online virtual event on June 28---July 2, 2021, with short courses offered on June 23---June 27, 2021. 

The original focus of this proposal was on funding for junior researchers (graduate students and postdoctoral researchers) from U.S.-based institutions to travel to the conference. With the approval of the NSF Statistics Program, the funds provided were then used during the no-cost extension for hosting the conference online, covering the IT costs and also establishing a Student/Postdoc Contributed Presentation competition as an incentive to encourage participation from junior researchers. A major objective was to make the event accessible to all, and in particular to encourage and facilitate participation from junior researchers including students and postdocs, especially those among underrepresented groups and those from institutions with limited resources who otherwise would not have been able to attend or participate in the meeting. 

With the support from this grant, the 2021 ISBA World Meeting was successfully held as a virtual conference. The theme of the conference was on theory, modeling, and applications of Bayesian statistics. The conference brought together a large international group of academics, researchers, professionals, government employees and students, from over 60 countries around the world. The support from this grant allowed the organizers to make the conference one of the most inclusive and accessible. Registrations for both the main conference and the short courses were made completely free to all, regardless of their membership status at ISBA. Consequently a historical record number of attendees registered and attended this meeting.

The Scientific Program included 5 Short Courses, 4 Foundational Lectures, 4 Keynote Lectures, 2 Named Lectures, 49 Invited Sessions, 31 Contributed Sessions, and 2 Poster Sessions. The program comprised a mixture of live talks, pre-recorded talks, and posters. Foundational, Keynote and Named Lectures, Invited Sessions, and Contributed Sessions were live-streamed and recorded for on-demand access. All live-streaming sessions were via Zoom, with links integrated into the Whova platform. Contributed talks were pre-recorded and were made available about two weeks before the conference. During the live-streamed Contributed Sessions, each speaker gave a 5-min live recap of their contributed talk, highlighting the main points, followed by live discussion and Q&A from the audience. Contributed speakers who had optionally chosen to accompany their talk with a poster also presented their poster in their designated Poster Session. Poster Sessions were held on Gather, which also served as the virtual space for social time during the whole conference.

In designing the format of the virtual conference, the Scientific Committee and the Organizing Committee together made several efforts to promote an inclusive and accessible environment and to increase participation from students, postdocs and other junior researchers. In particular, a new Contributed Presentation format was created, which was designed to give all researchers, especially students and postdocs, the opportunity to participate in the program. Each Contributed Presenter was able to present their work through a "15+5+poster" format consisting of a 15-min pre-recorded oral presentation, a 5-min live recap, and the option to also present a virtual poster. The pre-recorded oral presentations were uploaded by the speakers onto the Whova platform and made available about two weeks in advance of the conference so that attendees could use some time before the conference to watch them, and ask questions during the live sessions. About one third of the presenters decided to accompany their talk with an optional poster, participating in one of the two poster session days. Poster Sessions were held on Gather, a virtual space where people can move around and interact with each other through video/audio chats, imitating a real-world poster session experience. This new “15+5+poster” format helped bypass the limitation in the number of contributed oral talks in past World Meetings, and substantially improved participation from junior researchers. 

Twenty-one Contributed Presentations from students and postdocs were selected to receive the Best Student/Postdoc Contributed Paper Award. 

The funds of this grant covered the entire operating cost of this virtual conference including the license fees for the IT platform for hosting this conference---Whova, Zoom, and Gather---and for the Student/Postdoc Contributed Presentation Award Competition.
